review_preview: We discovered La Gastro de Chema last year on a local blog about Madrid's best croquettes and were eager to return and enjoy another lazy afternoon of croquetas & cava. Our waiter informed us that while the new menu featured their most popular croquetas, it...
review_full: We discovered La Gastro de Chema last year on a local blog about Madrid's best croquettes and were eager to return and enjoy another lazy afternoon of croquetas & cava. Our waiter informed us that while the new menu featured their most popular croquetas, it now also featured more varied tapas and platos. We shared the marinated boletus salad to start and the foie turr√≥n, simply amazing! The foie turr√≥n s something we had never tasted before but it is now reason enough for us to cross the Atlantic! Of course we had to have croquetas.. the boletus and truffle and the pork pibil croquetas reminded us why we were so eager to return. Next we had the Japo Coca with marinated Galician octopus and the Bocata Bao, fusion cooking at its best. Galicia has been serving octopus for hundreds of years before it became trendy and it was tender and beautifully presented, as was the Bao. Our waiter treated us to Mojito sorbets and they were just the right touch before dessert and expres√≥.  While we had so enjoyed the croqueta degustaci√≥n our last visit the new menu will tempt you even more. Can't wait to return!

review_preview: This is a lovely restaurant in a posh Madrid neighborhood.  Service was friendly, though erratic, it took a long time for food to arrive at times, even though we were the second or third table in the restaurant for lunch.  The menu was interesting, we...
review_full: This is a lovely restaurant in a posh Madrid neighborhood. Service was friendly, though erratic, it took a long time for food to arrive at times, even though we were the second or third table in the restaurant for lunch. The menu was interesting, we started with a mostly rare red tuna salad. The tuna had been slightly seared and was delicious, the salad was artfully and attractively prepared and was enough to feed two. Unfortunately both the wife and I found the dressing excessively acidic. We also had three tapas. The tosta de jamon was heaped with Iberico, on artisanal bread. Good. The vegetable tempera was vegetables cut and presented like french fries. Also good. The patatitas odds were stuffed potatoes, tasty and something different. I had a glass of wine, good quality but it seemed like the pour was less than in most similar places, while the price was more. That's an annoying combination.

review_preview: Odds is located in the best part of town.  The area is upscale yet the restaurant is "smart casual".  It is just as good a place for a business lunch as it is for a late night drink in its street side "terraza" or terrace...
review_full: Odds is located in the best part of town. The area is upscale yet the restaurant is "smart casual". It is just as good a place for a business lunch as it is for a late night drink in its street side "terraza" or terrace where we went. The menu is extensive and the food is artfully presented by the dedicated staff. The owner himself makes sure that the guests are happy with the service and the food. There is a lot of energy around. We had the seasonal grilled artichokes with smoked beef. It was very good. The wine selection is excellent too. We ordered a sampling of the desserts and all of them were tasty and creative. Great choice in Madrid!

title_review: Excellent place, one of the best we had in Madrid
review_preview: Excellent place with lovely outside seating next to a church and very nice inside with few rooms. There are many things on the menu and variety of raciones,  bigger dishes or also menus. We tried 5-6 dishes and they were all excellent. They have a...
review_full: Excellent place with lovely outside seating next to a church and very nice inside with few rooms. There are many things on the menu and variety of raciones, bigger dishes or also menus. We tried 5-6 dishes and they were all excellent. They have a variety of vey good salads ( not that common in Spain) and their beef steak was very good with potatoes with truffle oil! If for lunch, ask for the menu del dia - just 12,5 eur but includes first, second and a drink. Service was good, faster than other places in Madrid and they were polite. For desserts the lemon tart cake and tiramisu are awesome. They understand some English too. Overall, very recommended!

review_preview: From outside and inside the restaurant is well designed and gives good solid impression. Though it is not luxury, it's more relaxing democratic atmosphere. At first we faced some small troubles - it was Sunday before Farther's day, place was absolutelly full, running staff. Then,...
review_full: From outside and inside the restaurant is well designed and gives good solid impression. Though it is not luxury, it's more relaxing democratic atmosphere. At first we faced some small troubles - it was Sunday before Farther's day, place was absolutelly full, running staff. Then, for some reason, they didn't want to give some salad or vegetales instead of potatoes for my family member. And first time in my life I mentioned my TripAdviser level. And it worked! Amazing! They really cares about TripAdvisor. Actually our waiters Marta and Carlos were pleasant and skilled persons, the whole problem was originated in the kitchen. So after this small misunderstanding the rest of the lunch was perfect. You should try Lubina al sal, Raviolis con Ib√©ricos, Risotto with artichokes and asparagus. And as surprise for dessert we were invited by restaurant for Croquetas with Nutella and sweets with Oreo. Finally, it was very pleasant family meeting and we really enjoyed our time in this place.

review_preview: The restaurant is well designed and gives a nice first impression - but there it stops. We started with a bottle of red wine that proved to be ice cold and the waiter refused to change it as it was already open (rocket science?!), nor...
review_full: The restaurant is well designed and gives a nice first impression - but there it stops. We started with a bottle of red wine that proved to be ice cold and the waiter refused to change it as it was already open (rocket science?!), nor did we get to try the wine beforehand. I had tacos (both meat and octopus) for a starter, and the meat was so try I almost choked myself - I don't know if they had attempted to slow-cook the meat, but it was dry as Sahara. As not this was enough, I found a small piece of plastic in one of the tacos, but it might have been one of the ingredients they use to compensate for the quality of the meat. For my main course I had the steak tartare, which was medium++. What was poor is that my dish was served in a fish bowl, while my friends who also ordered it got plates. The fries served with the tartare were soggy and terrible, which makes me wonder if they fried them in water i stead of oil. All in all; If you are in Madrid there are hundreds of better, cheaper and better serviced restaurants.

title_review: Overpriced food, the rest is great
review_preview: Watch out - just because they're open doesn't mean they're serving food! Nice location, lots of outdoor seating with a very much appreciated intermittent water mist. Staff had very little English and were happy to meet me half way with my limited Spanish :) The...
review_full: Watch out - just because they're open doesn't mean they're serving food!  Nice location, lots of outdoor seating with a very much appreciated intermittent water mist. Staff had very little English and were happy to meet me half way with my limited Spanish :) The menu has good English translations. Generally great service. Drinks (soft and alcoholic) are on a par with Madrid prices and my strawberry Mojito was lovely, very strong and I loved the light bulb 'glass'! Funky touch.  If the food had been half the price this would be a five star rating. Very expensive for what you get - ‚Ç¨11 for a few pieces of meat ravioli in a mushroom sauce, almost ‚Ç¨10 for a dish of mixed veg from the plancha grill. Delicious, but not worth that much.  Maybe stop here for drinks (they brought free nibbles) then eat elsewhere.

title_review: Good Food, but bring some patience with you
review_preview: We (3) dined there on a Friday night at 8:00, we were lucky to get a table top that we shared with another couple.  I would highly recommend that you make a reservation.  An English menu is available.  I would say the menu has a...
review_full: We (3) dined there on a Friday night at 8:00, we were lucky to get a table top that we shared with another couple. I would highly recommend that you make a reservation. An English menu is available. I would say the menu has a wide number of choices, but viewing you it I tended to notice the seafood choices. We ordered fried chicken wings; salmon tar tar, a kebab dish (served as a sandwich/wrap); hamburger and fries; squid and a sausage & arrachera dish. All the options were good. As a seafood lover I really enjoyed the squid- it was cooked perfectly with sauteed onions on top. The Salmon tar tar was also very good with a mix of mango and lemon. My daughter and her friend ate mostly the beef & sausage dish (it was good, but I would not order it again). The hamburger was rare and but tasty. Can't go wrong with the fried chicken wings- but it's really not anything different than what you can get from other restaurants- didn't stand out. Cod Fritters nice cooked and light. We received most of our small plates within 10 to 15 minutes, but then waited about 40 minutes for the other dishes. I think they were slammed by some larger parties in the back room. After bringing the wait to the attention of our server, food was promptly served. The bill came to about 70 Euros- not too bad (no liquor). I think they felt bad for the wait so 2 shots on the house (I didn't want one) for the girls I would return to La Pescaderia, but only with a reservation in the back of the room. The high top where we sat at the front was too loud with too many people passing by to enjoy a family dinner- but that's personal preference. It's a really good choice before or after shopping/strolling along the Gran Via.

review_preview: If you're from anywhere in the US that has a large Latin American population, you'll know the croquet as a bready, savory, but sort of bland menu item.  The basic Spanish croquet, however, has a center with b√©chamel, and is much more flavorful.  La Gastro...
review_full: If you're from anywhere in the US that has a large Latin American population, you'll know the croquet as a bready, savory, but sort of bland menu item. The basic Spanish croquet, however, has a center with b√©chamel, and is much more flavorful. La Gastro Croqueteria takes this and simply runs with it, to all sorts of ends. The place was a short walk from our apartment, and we went there wo/reservations. We came as they opened, but they only managed to fit us in to a small table up front...everything else was taken. And where we were, you couldn't get the Special Tasting Menu. But we were so impressed with the a la cart menu that we made reservations for the only day we'd be in Madrid and they'd be open. It was the best meal we had in Madrid, and we had some good ones. And the price was amazingly affordable, for the quality of food and service. The tasting menu included savory and sweet croquets, soups, seafood, even a Kobe beef slider with sliced mushrooms on a corn bread slice. Each dish is presented with care, and the staff will explain to you what goes into each (they have very good English skills). The place is deservedly popular, so reservations are a must. You owe it to yourself to visit this if you're in Madrid, especially if you're anywhere near Gran Via.

review_full: This was a very good restaurant close to the Gran Via on a side street with outdoor seating. This is not a tapas bar but a sit down restaurant with a bar, inside tables and outdoor tables for smokers. The outdoor seating is in a high traffic area so it is more peaceful to eat inside. There are many menu items and we asked for olives as appetizers and were not charged for these. We had the Langostino Salteado and mini Parrillada which were excellent in flavor and presentation. The house wine was very tasty and reasonable in price. Bread was included as well as mineral water which made for a great reasonable priced meal. The service as attentive and fast. We highly recommend this restaurant!

review_preview: On one of the best streets in Madrid, Serrano 110, you‚Äôll find a delightful establishment serving elaborate Mediterranean food in an elegant environment. Odds restaurant prides itself on catering to an extraordinary diner, with a variety of culinary treats to please a range of guests....
review_full: On one of the best streets in Madrid, Serrano 110, you‚Äôll find a delightful establishment serving elaborate Mediterranean food in an elegant environment. Odds restaurant prides itself on catering to an extraordinary diner, with a variety of culinary treats to please a range of guests. They even offer specialty items for those sensitive to gluten.  Along with one of my dearest friends, I enjoyed a fabulous lunch in Salamanca at Odds Restaurant. The restaurant‚Äôs modern design drew us in immediately, as the fluidity of the curved chairs mixed with the straight angles of the square tables and bench seating heightened the contemporary feel. The restaurant also has a beautiful terrace right in the action of the city.  We took the server‚Äôs suggestion of sharing some appetizers, truly engaging in enjoying the gastronomic adventure together. We started with tuna belly and tomato tartare over guacamole with alfalfa sprouts and lime vinaigrette. Punchy and citrusy thanks to the tomato and lime flavor, this dish excited the taste buds. The sprouts added a nice crunch. We also opted for homemade croquettes, which are made every day and the fillings vary. The Foie Mi-cuit was delicious, cooked exactly as expected, and served with a sweet wine sauce on toasted bread. For my main, I chose stuffed meat ravioli with mushroom sauce, Parmesan cheese and truffle oil, which was earthy and balanced in flavor. My friend loved his grilled octopus with slowly cooked potatoes and red paprika oil, served on a stick. The octopus was expertly grilled, and the potatoes had a soft, creamy texture. The braised veal cheek stew over mashed potato cream seasoned with truffles was a major hit as well, a truly unique dish.  Not able to forgo dessert, we opted for a red velvet cupcake with violet ice cream, and fritters stuffed with chocolate and banana, served with wild red fruit sauce. Indulgent, sweet, decadent. A wonderful finish!

title_review: Great little place with OUTSTANDING flavor!!
review_preview: Decided to check out Gastro Croqueteria de Chema last night for a late dinner. They opened a little before their scheduled opening at 9pm, we were the first to sit down and by 9:15pm all of the tables were full! I'm glad we showed up...
review_full: Decided to check out Gastro Croqueteria de Chema last night for a late dinner. They opened a little before their scheduled opening at 9pm, we were the first to sit down and by 9:15pm all of the tables were full! I'm glad we showed up a bit early since we had not made a reservation, but they very graciously accommodated us anyway. There was one staff member who spoke English very well and the rest spoke a little so we were able to attempt a bit of our Spanish and were well taken care of. I tried brushing off a bit of my high school Spanish to get through the menu, and everything seemed quite interesting.  We opted for the Chef's 6 course tasting menu for ‚Ç¨18 per person. I was a little nervous at first (since I hate giving up control) that the Chef would decide to send us stuff that I wouldn't like! I didn't need to worry at all (although I really had no idea what I was eating) everything was OUTSTANDING! We started with an Aperitivo (some sort of vegetable), then we had a classic tapas dish (Russian salad). Next we received a large croqueta with a tray of thinly sliced onion, chopped tomato and minced pickled jalape√±os- all served with a small basket of nacho chips. We were told to cut the croqueta open (filled with gooey melted cheese - YUM!) and add as much of the fixins as one wanted then close it up and use the chips to dip into the concoction. Then we were given 2 types of croquetas to try - I think one was chicken and the other was potato and cheese (not sure though!)- but DELICIOUS nonetheless. Lastly we were offered mini street tacos that were smoky and very flavorful! After such a delectable dinner, we decided to splurge and order some dessert. We opted for their Sorbete de Mojito. It seemed self explanatory- Mojito Sorbet.....right? Wrong! It turned out that would have been too boring for such an inventive and eclectic restaurant. When the dessert arrived it was in a small individual sized milk bottle with a straw sticking out the top. It turns out they had made it into a very minty (at least 5 full mint leaves inside!) and refreshing, thick shake!  All in all we had a wonderful dinner, and if time allows, would love to come back for another meal before we leave Madrid. A real treat for the palate! The staff were very welcoming and attentive, although they were very busy (since the place was packed!) and worked with us and our poor grasp of Spanish.

title_review: A temple devoted to the croqueta!
review_preview: By the end of your time in Spain you might be a tad fed up with croquets but a visit to the croqueteria will quickly revive your interest. This pleasantly decorated restaurant lets you order a la carte or from several set menus including a...
review_full: By the end of your time in Spain you might be a tad fed up with croquets but a visit to the croqueteria will quickly revive your interest. This pleasantly decorated restaurant lets you order a la carte or from several set menus including a tasting or degustacion menu and the rage of savoury croquets is astonishing. Try the tuna, calamari, mushroom and cheese ones. And the dessert croquets are truly astonishing. Sample the one made with Oreos! You can book here or you can try your luck by just walking in. The Croqueteria is not far north of the Gran Via so it was an easy walk for me. Friendly service even for Spanish-challenged folks. Oh, and there are other things to order from the menu if you don't want croquets!

review_preview: You can't even call these croquetas if you compare them to the de-thawed pieces of fried bechamel they serve as other establishments. These are some of the most elaborate, decadent, flavorful croquetas I've ever tried; you pay for it, but it's worth it to experience...
review_full: You can't even call these croquetas if you compare them to the de-thawed pieces of fried bechamel they serve as other establishments. These are some of the most elaborate, decadent, flavorful croquetas I've ever tried; you pay for it, but it's worth it to experience these gourmet bombs. When you order a few particular varieties of croqueta they even advise you to eat in one bite because they literally explode as soon as you sink your teeth in. We tried four varieties of croquetas and our favorite was the "liquidas de queso". The others we tried were also amazing and I'd definitely eat ANY of them again. We ordered a couple of the side dishes, which were okay, but the main spotlight of the meal was the croquetas. Next time I'd order more croquetas and less dishes.

title_review: Excellent food, excellent service, excellent location
review_preview: Last weekend I was looking for a place to have a nice dinner with a few friends around barrio Salamanca and while walking down Serrano we found Odds.Although it was quite early for Spanish standards (21.00) there were only a few tables available and...
review_full: Last weekend I was looking for a place to have a nice dinner with a few friends around barrio Salamanca and while walking down Serrano we found Odds. Although it was quite early for Spanish standards (21.00) there were only a few tables available and the maitre sat us down on the terrace.  We couldn't have made a better choice. We ordered various plates. The ox tail hamburger was amazing, lemon chicken, tomato tartar with tuna also and the lime pie and pineapple mojito were the icing on the cake. We stayed until 1am having a few drinks and the place was booming.  The owner (who speaks perfect English) was very kind, invited us to a typical Spanish liqcour and the waiters were flawless. I recommend this place to anyone who wants to eat very well, in a great place, great location with a great ambience and a very reasonable price (29 eur with a drink or two each). I will be back.

title_review: Make reservations - but make sure you go!
review_preview: We did not make reservations. The server was amazing. I mean, he deserves 10 stars for how great he is (and I'm a jerk that I do not remember his name). Tall, dark, and from South America - I don't speak Spanish, but his English...
review_full: We did not make reservations. The server was amazing. I mean, he deserves 10 stars for how great he is (and I'm a jerk that I do not remember his name).  Tall, dark, and from South America - I don't speak Spanish, but his English accent was different -- how I guessed he wasn't from Spain.  Anyways, we got to the Gastro pub and he told us he had no tables, but hang out and have some wine and he would take care of us - and he did. A spot opened up at the counter and he saved it for us and got us there.  I had no idea what to order, so he helped me order by what I like, sweet, sour, what kind of meat, etc. I could not have been happier with the service, selection, or croquettes.  Go hungry, and order a lot! And get dessert! And then get more dessert! Everything is reasonably priced, the wine flowed, amazing gin and tonics, I cannot say enough positive things about this restaurant.  I do suggest making a reservation - it was packed. I am not sure how far in advance, but I do feel lucky that the server got us a spot!

review_preview: We had booked for a large party - 14 - and arrived on time 10pm. The table was not quite ready upon arrival but that was not a problem. We eventually sat down but then it took some time for the menus to arrive and...
review_full: We had booked for a large party - 14 - and arrived on time 10pm. The table was not quite ready upon arrival but that was not a problem. We eventually sat down but then it took some time for the menus to arrive and especially the wine list so that we could order drinks.  There didn't seem to be one person in charge of our table and the order taking was very haphazard.  The food when it came was excellent but one of our starte dishes was the cheese fondue which arrived unaccompanied so with nothing to dip it with or eat it with. Bread had not been served at the table (very unusual in Spain) so we asked that this be served - after some 10 minutes we were told that it was being made - so a long delay whilst we waited for the bread - probably 25 minutes later the bread arrived and we got on with the fabulous fondue. Main course was subsequently served but the meat dishes with their juices were served on flat slates - big mistake- since when serving the juices dripped onto the guests !!! Surely they should know better! Then to cap it all at the end of the meal and deserts etc some guests ordered some drinks (g&t etc) which were served at 0100 - 5 minutes later we were told that we could no longer stay on the terrace but had to go indoors since they did not have a permit for people to sit on the terrace after 0100 - so why didn't they serve the drinks indoors and invite us inside for the drinks.  A Big Disappointment for all and quite obvious that there are problems with their service levels especially when serving on the terrace.

review_full: I've eaten at plenty of places in Madrid but La Pescaderia really stands out. It's got it all - a trendy interior, good atmosphere, good service, decent prices and most importantly, a strong menu of really tasty food. They serve modern tapas which you can order to share, or main courses. I usually order a few tapas to share with friends which is great value. Stand-out dishes are the pumpkin and goat's cheese salad, the cod fritters and the chipirones. The patatas bravas here are also great, a bit different to the standard offering. Wines are also reasonably priced, and you can order cocktails. I recommend booking if you're going at the weekend - you can book online.

title_review: Great food (and drinks!), nice atmosphere, good service.
review_preview: I count myself lucky to be living in the centre of Madrid, a stone's throw from some amazing restaurants (check out my other reviews on Dstage and NextDoor). Pescaderia (literally "fish market", although it also serves meats) is one of those. You can book through...
review_full: I count myself lucky to be living in the centre of Madrid, a stone's throw from some amazing restaurants (check out my other reviews on Dstage and NextDoor). Pescaderia (literally "fish market", although it also serves meats) is one of those. You can book through the website, or give them a call. You can also eat at the bar without a booking. It gets fantastically busy during the weekend, so it pays to do your homework beforehand and reserve a table. Together with my group of friends, we decided to honour the name of the restaurant and order predominantly fish dishes. In true Spanish tapas tradition we were also going to share everything, which I believe to be the correct thing to do at this restaurant, even if the menu is divided into appetisers to share and main courses. The langostinos salteados (saut√©ed prawns), with avocado and mango, stood out from everything else and were truly delicious; the chipirones frescos encebollados (grilled calamari with onions) came a close second; and the carpaccio de pulpo (octopus carpaccio) in an oil vinegrette was truly paper thin - a welcome change from the omnipresent pulpo a la gallega you find at most tapas restaurants and that I am not so keen on. I also need to mention the ceviche and the Greek salad - both of which were very tasty. The portions are not that small and after all of this the three of us were full.  Drinks deserve their own separate chapter in this review: both the original pisco sour (Peru's best known alcoholic export), and its maracuja declination were delicious. If its not food that you are after, you might want to go in just to experience those two delicious drinks. I will be back to check the rest of the range. The service was spotless: fast and pleasant. Food was brought almost instantly, empty glasses and plates were whisked away in a millisecond, and cutlery changed in between courses. Considering the restaurant was bursting with people, this is nothing short of operational excellence.  For such a small and unassuming restaurant from the outside, the place features design interiors and a very nice bar. The Malasana buzz will conquer you. For this quality, the price is absolutely reasonable - we paid Euro 30 each, including drinks. Highly recommended.

review_full: The Gastro croqueteria of Chema has a perfect location, very near to the centre. The restaurant is decorated in a trendy and cozy way. The most fascinating thing is the great variety and combination of croquettes that they have, I would like to have tasted all of them without any doubt. Regarding to the other dishes they have I will say they are delicious. Maybe the size of the portion was not so big, but correct in order to taste the delicious mixtures. We were six and all of us were fascinated about the quality of the food. We decided to share the portions, so we could taste more dishes, just some bites. I would like to notice the "fideua con costra", more than you can ever expect. Also the lamb with potatoes or the shabu shabu of balck cod. As desserts we ordered all the sweet croquettes, which were very tasty and surprising, my favourite was the oreo croquette. The price was correct, we did not finish too full, but we enjoyed the food as much as we could. The waiters and waitresses were pleasant and helpful. I strongly believe that the Gastro croqueteria of Chema deserves more than one visit and I hope to back soon.

title_review: The food is full of surprises! Passion!
review_preview: We decided to give this little restaurant a try after looking at local reviews of a food directory. The restaurant owners are a couple: man being the chef and the girl the waitress . The place is small but cosy, only 10 tables or so....
review_full: We decided to give this little restaurant a try after looking at local reviews of a food directory. The restaurant owners are a couple: man being the chef and the girl the waitress . The place is small but cosy, only 10 tables or so. We tried the tasting menu which consisted of a few dishes which had won some award at some food competition.  The girl was very patient to explain everything in English.  The tomato soup was refreshing with a little quail egg and the presentation was nice. Next we had the creamiest foie gas p√¢t√© we had ever tasted with a nice combination with some special Spanish Christmas cookies. That was unexpectedly good. Next we had a piece of thin ham with salmon roe and some herbs on top which we needed to make it into a roll with food tweezers. The grilled lamb was marvelous with it being cooked just right and succelent . The dessert was special flavour ice cream with rice.  There was only the girl taking orders, presenting the dishes and taking away the dishes, making coffee and settling bills. We were amazed at how she did all these at ease. Te chef had actually won a 2014 best chef award somewhere . We didn't really go because he had won a prize, but certainly we felt that the food was made and served with passion.  Would certainly return!

review_preview: We stumbled across this charming little hideaway restaurant by accident looking for a low key, relaxed first evening in Madrid.This was a little gem with plenty of exciting variations on this classic Spanish tapas staple snack. The setting was small and intimate, with arched...
review_full: We stumbled across this charming little hideaway restaurant by accident looking for a low key, relaxed first evening in Madrid. This was a little gem with plenty of exciting variations on this classic Spanish tapas staple snack. The setting was small and intimate, with arched white ceilings and eclectic fixtures. They did not have an English menu but the wonderfully friendly waitress offered to to translate as best she could. However we plumped for the menu of the day, which consisted of 6 tapas dishes of the chef's choice. All were mouth wateringly good, a diverse range and served freshly cooked. As the dishes were delivered from kitchen to the tables around the restaurant, I could see diners cooing and leaning over to look at the gorgeously presented morsels (myself included). From the simple classic beef tomato stuffed with mozzarella on a bed of delicate olive tapenade, which came with a syringe of pesto oil sticking out to inject within; to the prawn and squid baked noodles in sweet, tasty aioli, these tasty courses exploded with flavour.

We were sitting at a table inside the door by the cigarette machine and Maria was busy feeding an envelope of coins into the machine which was very annoying and when she was asked to serve us she walked away, another member of staff took our order for a glass of white wine which was then delivered by Maria, she poured the wine from a nearly empty bottle but stopped pouring when there was a tiny amount left, she refused to pour this into the glass and when we jokingly said something about pouring it in she shrugged and left. I‚Äôm pretty sure that the small amount left was going to be discarded and I felt she was ‚Äúpunishing‚Äù us for interrupting her mission to use the cigarette machine to change up her envelope of small coins. Perhaps Maria needs a little lesson on customer service! We decided not to let this experience deter us from visiting again the next evening and we were not disappointed, once gain the service and food were amazing and I would highly recommend trying the restaurant.

Service was ok; the waitress was attentive and spoke a little English for my non-Spanish-speaking colleague. Both of us had the squid dish (chipirones), which really was very good, with a tomato and sweet peppers garnish. But I'd ordered a cold soup starter of Salmorejo de la Casa and disappointingly that actually arrived only after I'd finished my chipirones. So, while still worth a visit, this place wasn't top top notch.

review_preview: We booked a few weeks in advance, requesting at the time the "Degustacion Umami." It consisted of 2 starters - one of which was scallop carpaccio with a caviar vinaigrette, I can't even talk about it without my mouth watering - 6 main courses, and...
review_full: We booked a few weeks in advance, requesting at the time the "Degustacion Umami." It consisted of 2 starters - one of which was scallop carpaccio with a caviar vinaigrette, I can't even talk about it without my mouth watering - 6 main courses, and 2 desserts, and it cost less than 40 euros. Because we are ridiculous people, we also ordered two croquetas - one with blue cheese and the other I can't recall at the moment. They were delicious, as well, but not as special as the special menu items. The desserts we had were very savory (beet and goat cheese souffle kind of thing), but that may be because I am allergic to cocoa and apples, two obvious dessert ingredients (by the way, they were very accommodating for my allergies - asked right at the beginning). We nearly went back the next night, but decided to go watch a football match instead (Madrid vs. Atletico - could not miss!). The only "critique" I would make is that service is VERY fast. On the one hand, you have 10 courses, so it still takes a long time to eat (I think we were there for 2.5 hours), but on the other hand, I would have preferred about 5 minutes between dishes to reflect on how fantastic they were. We mentioned it to the server (who was wonderful), and he said that was the style in Madrid - apparently Madrilenos like to have have their food right away.  Fantastic! Book in advance, as there was a line out the door when we arrived for our reservation.

The value for money is superb and if only we lived in Madrid we would be regulars ! Don't miss this restaurant

review_preview: I'd spotted this place via TripAdvisor before we even left for Spain - and highlighted it for a breakfast visit since it was located close to our hotel. We weren't disappointed!The cafe is not large, but we found a table for two and were...
review_full: I'd spotted this place via TripAdvisor before we even left for Spain - and highlighted it for a breakfast visit since it was located close to our hotel. We weren't disappointed! The cafe is not large, but we found a table for two and were quickly served what we came in for: thick hot chocolate for dipping, freshly squeezed orange juice, coffee - and a portion each if thin Churros and thicker Porros (just to compare of course!). Both were very tasty - hot (just cooked) and crunchy.  I preferred the thicker and more doughnutty Porros; my daughter liked the crunchier Churros. We were both happy. And then happily trotted off to the Reina Sofia to see some bonkers art... With breakfast at our hotel at ‚Ç¨16 per person, this local alternative at less than ‚Ç¨10 for the two of us was a bit of a no-brainer. Go!

title_review: A great chocolate con churros place!
review_preview: I came here with the Madrid Food Tour and was pleasantly surprised. Honestly, I would have never walked in had I been alone: I live in Madrid and would have stayed far from a small corner bar with large posters and banners advertising cheap chocolate...
review_full: I came here with the Madrid Food Tour and was pleasantly surprised. Honestly, I would have never walked in had I been alone: I live in Madrid and would have stayed far from a small corner bar with large posters and banners advertising cheap chocolate products.  With photos. However, trusting the guide, we all heaped in (the place isn't very big) and waited for what is basically the best hot chocolate I've ever eaten in Madrid. And I've been here a year and a half. Rich, thick, not sweetened. The porras (which we had instead of churros) made to order: hot, crunchy and delicious. The staff was friendly and spoke quite a good English.  On the whole, a pretty good experience. I will probably send friends and family to this place instead of the less-friendly albeit more famous San Gines. ;) Good job!

Orange juice is freshly squeeze in this cute little machine. Was fun to just look at the juicer. I'd recommend this place anything other the other famous place in Madrid. It's a about 5 minutes walk from Anton Martin Station. Oh and service was good here. The guy with the glasses was the nicest of the lot.

title_review: More than you can dream of!
review_preview: More free food and drinks that you could possibly dream of! Found this place of mere accident while looking for a place to eat. The prices were fair but with a plosttwist, which was the free samples of different food they gave you. They gave...
review_full: More free food and drinks that you could possibly dream of! Found this place of mere accident while looking for a place to eat. The prices were fair but with a plosttwist, which was the free samples of different food they gave you. They gave us free glasses of wine, some things for dessert and the free apitizers were excellent, lots of bread and other snacks that went along perfectly with the meal. Hell, towards the end of the night they even gave out some free spanish booze, so it was definitely worth the money. The service was as good as it gets and it's just a walk away from Puerta del Sol so this is a must for any couple or family for that matter.  Highly recommended!

review_preview: Staying in the Tryp Ambassador hotel we decided to try this restaurant around the corner based on the menu options, ambience, and reasonable prices.  Although you can sit outside we opted to eat indoors and enjoyed the background music and atmosphere even before the complimentary...
review_full: Staying in the Tryp Ambassador hotel we decided to try this restaurant around the corner based on the menu options, ambience, and reasonable prices. Although you can sit outside we opted to eat indoors and enjoyed the background music and atmosphere even before the complimentary glasses of cava arrived, the first of our pleasant surprises! Service was prompt and both of our attentive and helpful waitresses understood English. A Maitre'd also hovered and kept a close eye on proceedings ensuring a good standard of service. Steaks are reasonably priced between ‚Ç¨18 and ‚Ç¨24, with choices including Ribeye, Sirloin and thin skirt varieties (the Ribeye is particularly good), but more than steak is on offer and they also have a tapas menu that is very keenly priced. We decided not to order a starter but two cups of gazpacho arrived with toasted bread and a cream cheese dip mixed with chives and orange which was thoughtful, tasty and free. French fries may seem expensive at ‚Ç¨6 but the portion serves two. Feeling sated after an excellent meal we were given a glass of mango juice on the house and then, having decided to forego dessert, two glasses of fruit compote topped with cream arrived followed by two shot glasses accompanied by a generous portion of limoncello. All told including tip this meal cost ‚Ç¨80 and represented excellent value for money, so much so we went a second time two nights later!

review_preview: We chose this restaurant for our last night in Madrid and were very happy about the choice. The food is great (our steaks were perfectly cooked, the accompanied asparagus extremely tasty, and the dessert flan and millefeuille huge and delicious). Besides these ordered dishes we...
review_full: We chose this restaurant for our last night in Madrid and were very happy about the choice. The food is great (our steaks were perfectly cooked, the accompanied asparagus extremely tasty, and the dessert flan and millefeuille huge and delicious). Besides these ordered dishes we got a vegetable starter soup (which was good but not very original), small extra desserts (delicious lemon drink and mango yoghurt shot) and digestive drinks, for free. With a glass of wine this meal cost about 50eur per person, which is quite cheap compared to my country. Our waiter did not speak very much English but she was fast, helpful and friendly and asked her colleague to help when needed. The restaurant is beautiful and tidy and its location great. The steak may have been the best I've ever eaten and I will definitely visit this restaurant when I'm in Madrid again.

My rib eye steak was excellent, cooked just short of medium with a charcoaled outside. Our other dish was the beef ribs. We shared a salad and one portion of chips. More than enough for two. The cost was very reasonable for the quality of the food. We had a wait for the bill as the place got very busy and we noticed as it got later that some people had quite a wait to have their orders taken. But the ambience is good and if you're not in a hurry, that's not a problem. I would certainly revisit.

They offered dinner early, so we sat down to eat at 6:30 pm before going to a nearby flamenco show. We were pleasantly surprised to be served a complimentary glass of sparkling wine and small gazpacho appetizer. The interesting salads were large enough for two people to share as a starter. All of our main courses were delicious. We did not order dessert, but were served complimentary small dishes of blueberries with cream, and mango coolers. They were ready to serve us a complimentary liquor, but we had to leave for our show. The waiters were friendly and attentive. All in all, this was a great value for one of the best dinners that we had on our trip.

title_review: Good steak restaurant right off the Opera
review_preview: They immediately serve you a glass of Rose Cava to start. Location is perfect, if you get a table outside, there are some plants that kind of insulate you from the crowds, which can get lively and raucous. (there were a couple of dozen teenage...
review_full: They immediately serve you a glass of Rose Cava to start. Location is perfect, if you get a table outside, there are some plants that kind of insulate you from the crowds, which can get lively and raucous. (there were a couple of dozen teenage kids in the square and some sort of scuffle, maybe a lovers quarrel that brought the local Policia - nothing very violent though). If you are allergic to cigarette smoke, get a table inside as patrons who sit outside will smoke, and on hot days they will be running the mist machine and it kinda gets into your food. We ordered one each of the sirloin, rib-eye and skirt steak. They're all grilled to your proper temperature and all of them are good quality beef (although not Lugers or Homestead steakhouse level). They ask you to order sides and each one, like the fries and backed potato are each one large enough for 3-4 people, so you don't need more than 1 or 2 for a party of 3-6.  We ordered wine but once again got served some free mango cocktail when we ordered dessert - the Flan was excellent. Additionally, we were given a yougurt-blueberry cup which was delicious, again gratis.  Finally after dessert and espresso - they brought out a small decanter of some greenish liquor which tasted like absinthe, for free! What? Yea it was crazy. Not sure what it was, but gets the job done Servers are professional and courteous and very efficient. Overall a great value if you like a lot of freebie alcohol (and who doesn't?) Better be hungry when you come here, there's a lot of food served.

title_review: Insulting and unacceptable behaviour by restaurant manager
review_preview: This is intended to be an honest, balanced and constructive assessment of our experience at this restaurant in mid-September 2015. My wife, a vegan, and I had eaten there several times in the past and had always been very satisfied, so we had been looking...
review_full: This is intended to be an honest, balanced and constructive assessment of our experience at this restaurant in mid-September 2015. My wife, a vegan, and I had eaten there several times in the past and had always been very satisfied, so we had been looking forward to going there again. We were made welcome by the courteous waiter and received the customary small but excellent starter dishes and a glass of sparkling wine. We then ordered our food, and explained that my wife does not eat anything from an animal, i.e. no meat, no fish, no eggs, no cheese etc. The staff assured us that the pasta dish would meet these requirements. When the pasta arrived (after a delicious salad starter) we found that it was topped with three rather long pieces of cheese, which we removed immediately. But it was then found that the dish contained large quantities of egg in the sauce. We called the waiter, who took the dish away. Several minutes later the manager arrived and asked for an explanation. He started to argue, so I walked out of the restaurant and asked him to join me there so that other customers would not be inconvenienced. He argued that Italian pasta contains egg (we were in Spain, not Italy) and ignored the issue of the cheese. I told him we would not pay for the dish and returned to the table. Several minutes later he came back with a revised bill. But he started shouting at my wife (not me) and was VERY rude to her. Everybody in the restaurant heard what he said, and I apologised to the guests at the neighbouring tables. The man is the rudest person we have ever met in any restaurant in the world. His staff got the order wrong but he was not willing to accept responsibility. The inedible dish cost ‚Ç¨15, so the restaurant has lost virtually nothing except its reputation. This was a truly terrible and disgusting experience, especially after such good meals in the past. If you go there and do not like a dish, think before you complain, unless you want to be insulted by an ignorant male chauvinist.

review_preview: We liked this place best of the six restaurants we tried, so we returned for a second visit, which was equally good. Do reserve--walk-ins are usually turned away because the place is quite popular. Our favorites included Gambas al Ajillo (garlic shrimp,) but note that...
review_full: We liked this place best of the six restaurants we tried, so we returned for a second visit, which was equally good. Do reserve--walk-ins are usually turned away because the place is quite popular. Our favorites included Gambas al Ajillo (garlic shrimp,) but note that they were accidentally left off the English version of the menu, the patatas bravas, and the chipirones cencebolla (squid with red onions.) Also good were the baby cheesburger, and the higado encebollado (liver with onions.) The wines were good as well, the ‚Ç¨15 chardonnay and the ‚Ç¨18 red. The desserts were unimpressive (like most that we tried in Madrid.) We tried tarta de Lima Merenga, tarta de Chocolate, and tarta Casera Zanah. All were okay. NB: although the address is on Calle Ballesta, it's a nicer walk if you take Corredera Baja de San Pablo. La Pescaderia is at the intersection of the two streets. btw, our second best restaurants (a tie) were Restaurante Morgana and Bar Galleta.

review_full: I absolutely love this restaurant! First of all let me just say that if you want to eat at 'spanish time' i.e 8pm onward then book in advance as it will be super busy. The decor in this restaurant is awesome. I especially love the banksy art and the bathroom. The staff here are very nice and speak Spanish and English fluently. They also have a menu in English. Now let me get to the food. The selection is great, not just your typical Spanish tapas. I highly recommend the prawns with avocado and mango and the cod fritters. I also have to say that the patatas bravas are the best I have ever had. Well worth the visit if you go to Madrid.

We shared a plate of Patatas Bravas as well as a salad of avocado, tomato with a pesto style dressing. Very nicely presented and very tasty. The Kebab de cerdo Iberico con salsa de yogurt picante along with dish of the day Entrecote were both stunning choices - the Kebab is a signature dish of the restaurant i believe and delivers fantastic taste, textures.  The service was charming, friendly and very quick. Highly recommend!

title_review: Delicious food and great service - Highly recommend!
review_preview: La Pescaderia came highly recommended by our air bnb host so we thought we should check it out. We tried to get a reservation for 2 different nights but they were fully booked except for a space at 10.30pm. For a Brit this is late...
review_full: La Pescaderia came highly recommended by our air bnb host so we thought we should check it out.  We tried to get a reservation for 2 different nights but they were fully booked except for a space at 10.30pm. For a Brit this is late to be eating but we thought this place must be worth it.  And we were right, the food was delicious and the service was excellent. The restaurant was extremely busy but the staff were still attentive and rushing around to accommodate everyone.  We had some tacos for starters, which were fresh and flavoursome although a little too much sea salt. The prawn, mango and avocado salad was absolutely delicious as was the lamb kebab. Our vegetarian friend had risotto, which she said was great too.  For dessert we shared the carrot cake which was moist and also wonderful.  Our best dinner in Madrid for sure!

review_preview: We just came across this place, but, what a find! The outdoor area was great, the heaters we well positioned so we weren't cooking and each chair had a blanket! The complimentary champagne, bread and cheese spread was a nice little suprise and delicious! The...
review_full: We just came across this place, but, what a find!  The outdoor area was great, the heaters we well positioned so we weren't cooking and each chair had a blanket!  The complimentary champagne, bread and cheese spread was a nice little suprise and delicious!  The staff were quick, friendly and efficient.  We ordered the pesto pasta and asado. Honestly, the asado was amazing, perfectly cooked and the chimmichurri was spot on. The pesto was delicious and a good size serving.  Just when we thought we had enough, the waiter brings out a complimentary limoncello? And mango/yogurt mini dessert. Both, delicious and a perfect way to end our dinner.  But no, out come the complimentary after dinner liquors, which my husband enjoyed several of as they leave them at the table.  Well priced, not budget but moderate. They had indoor and outdoor seating. The staff is friendly and they understand English. It's in a great spot, there's plenty of shops around if you feel like going for a walk after the dinner. Definetely recommend this place! You won't be disappointed!

title_review: Nice meats, good location, great service, but very touristy
review_preview: This was our fist dinner in Madrid having arrived a couple of hours before.De Mario was around the corner from our hotel, so very convenient.We booked a table and were served in the upstairs room with a nice view of the Opera.Service...
review_full: This was our fist dinner in Madrid having arrived a couple of hours before. De Mario was around the corner from our hotel, so very convenient. We booked a table and were served in the upstairs room with a nice view of the Opera. Service was extremelly friendly. We had our dedicated waitress who looked after us the whole meal. They served us a free glass of "champagne" (local drink really), some free appetisers, like delicious tomato soup, toasts etc... if you have a small appetite, like my wife, beware, you might be full before your food arrives :) The meat (ribeye) was extremelly tender and tasty but not very cheap (25‚Ç¨) given that sides are all extras (fries are super pricey at 6‚Ç¨!!).. The wine we drank was on the other hand amazing value for money (top Rioja 2010 for 25‚Ç¨!) All in all, we paid 120‚Ç¨ for 3, which is not cheap by Madrid standards, but given location and service, was fine with us.

review_preview: For a restaurant facing the entrance to the Opera House in the heart of Madrid, the De Maria offers a superb quality dining experience at a really remarkable price. With an outside dining area bordering the square and a good sized inside serving space, this...
review_full: For a restaurant facing the entrance to the Opera House in the heart of Madrid, the De Maria offers a superb quality dining experience at a really remarkable price. With an outside dining area bordering the square and a good sized inside serving space, this restaurant oozes ambience, and is well patronised by locals and visitors alike. The menu is varied (the lemon chicken particularly good) with some dishes prepared on the open grill. Service is prompt, polite and helpful, the wine list wide, varied and well priced. The restaurant is tastefully decorated, spotlessly clean and free from the annoying background music which seems to be omnipresent at most other eateries! Particularly appreciated was the glass (free) of Cava, the free appetiser and the free liqueur at the end of the meal! Two courses (a la carte) for two people, with a bottle of good wine and coffee, all for 70Euro - outstanding value for quality food and atmosphere.

title_review: Was hoping for a little more...
review_preview: In my search along the narrow streets of Madrid for a 'menu del dia' of which there are so many to choose from, I choose La Pesaderia. It looked presentable from the outside and there were several people seated at the outdoor tables which is...
review_full: In my search along the narrow streets of Madrid for a 'menu del dia' of which there are so many to choose from, I choose La Pesaderia. It looked presentable from the outside and there were several people seated at the outdoor tables which is usually a good sign. Sadly my experience didn't measure up to my expectations. I sat at a table on the street waiting for the server to approach me but the minutes ticked by and he seemed to forget about me. I attempted to make eye contact several times even waving my hand to get his attention but nothing worked. A woman standing on the street watching noticed my attempts and finally said something to him and he finally came over. I ordered the special menu del dia. Usually with these types of specials you have a choice of the primero and possibly a choice of segundo. There was only a choice for the primero. I asked for recommendations and based on his information I told him which items I wanted and asked for a glass of wine. My primero was brought to me within 5-10 minutes. I ordered the Caldo de Reina which is a soup. What I received was a broth with a soft egg floating in it....not terribly impressive. I finished the soup and sat for about 15 minutes before my segundo was brought. This was a baked fish. As the waitress delivering the dish to me placed the plate down in front of me I asked her where my wine was? She looked surprised and I immediately attempted to make eye contact with the main waiter and asked him where my wine was...oops he forgot! I started eating while waiting for my wine to arrive. The fish was over cooked and dry and full of many tiny bones. I kept having to remove these from my mouth every mouthful which I found annoying. The bread served was dry and somewhat stale and there was no sauce to moisten it with or oil offered. Up finishing, I again sat for about 20 min without anyone coming to take away my plate which was now attracting wasps flying around it. I had to wave again to get the waiters attention and get him to come over and remove the dishes. I was also surprised that no water was offered or brought to me. I knew there was a postre with the special so I looked on the menu while sitting to see what the choices were so I could order as soon as he arrived. When I told him which one I wanted he told me that one was not with the special...so I had to choose from the ones he was telling me. I took the tiramiso which actually was probably the best thing and I doubt it was made in house! Sorry La Pescaderia but for 12.50euros I expected better!

review_full: I'm a true fan of ceviche, so we came here to have it. While we were waiting (the restaurant gets quite full, so book your reservation), we had a beer and a Bloody Mary at the bar. Great drinks while we waited. The restaurant itself is nice (but noisy, like all in Spain), with a nice decoration and an outdoor terraza. The prices are medium, the quality is good/very good, and the fish was fresh. Regarding the dishes, I was only disappointed by the amount of fish in the meagre ceviche, that was around 18‚Ç¨ and had little fish, when compared to the salmon tartar we asked for. Apart from that, I recommend this restaurant.

review_preview: We¬¥ve been to several other places, including the most popular, but Chocolat is an excellent choice for chocolate and churros while in Mardrid.  The Hot Chocolate is thick and very rich.  The churros are also excellent.This is a small and cozy location.  The area...
review_full: We¬¥ve been to several other places, including the most popular, but Chocolat is an excellent choice for chocolate and churros while in Mardrid. The Hot Chocolate is thick and very rich. The churros are also excellent. This is a small and cozy location. The area where it is located is very scenic and inviting. And unlike some of the other better known location, the service here is exceptionally friendly. You will see many more locals than tourists. Prices are good and the breakfast sandwiches that we saw others had ordered looked very good as well. Overall a very friendly and pleasant experience. We will return here before we return to the other better known places. Bathrooms were also very clean.

title_review: So good, we came here two nights running
review_preview: Fantastic evening meal here two nights in a row. Near to our hotel (TRYP Ambassador), and with a pleasant interior and heated terrace. The first surprise was a complimentary glass of bubbly, and a glass of soup with crispy toast with herby butter; this was...
review_full: Fantastic evening meal here two nights in a row. Near to our hotel (TRYP Ambassador), and with a pleasant interior and heated terrace. The first surprise was a complimentary glass of bubbly, and a glass of soup with crispy toast with herby butter; this was in addition to the delicious bread. The chicken with lemon main was fabulous: grilled in front of us and vey moist. The chips were enough to share between us. The wine to accompany the meal was good value (we chose a Tempranillo at 13euro). We were then in for another surprise: a complimentary glass of mango sorbet, a yoghurt-based desert with coulis, and some patcharan!! We were slightly worried that we would be charged for all the extras, but no! The food was great, service very efficient, but the complimentary extras made this a memorable evening. We will be back!

Directed to a table on the terrace(as there is a 10% service charge, fly I know) Chairs pulled out for us. As soon as we sat down they put on another heat lamp aiming at us. Our order was taken after some free cava was poured. You will hear "on the house" a lot here and it is all free! Who doesn't like free stuff?! We then had a couple of started dishes brought out to us on the house. Including a shot like glass of soup nice touch in February. Food was excellent! No faults! Only thing I would say is some dishes are over priced, example is a plain plate of chips was around 6‚Ç¨. Steaks were 18-24 which is good for steaks. They only had sirloin cut, which is not my favourite. If you are british o highly reccomend the black pudding starter! After our meal we were give an a small ap√©ritif of sambuca. My partner loved it but I cant touch the stuff. Also a free strawberry compote desert. Service is very attentive also. For prices sake we had a starter and main each, a side of chips and a wine it came to around 55‚Ç¨ Which is good value for the quality of food and service. Extra props to the manager as the restaurant is located in a plaza which can be popular with homeless. A couple tried to come in and ask for money at the table but the manager swiftly and politely escorts them out. It is a shame but not pleasant when your trying to enjoy an evening out. All you need to say to them is "no hablo espanol" it means I don't speak Spanish and you will be left alone!

title_review: Great restaurant with some minor flaws
review_preview: My partner and I dined here last night after looking for a fancier place to have dinner in Madrid. We came across this place which seemed lovely and not too expensive compared to others we had looked at. We chose a table outside which despite...
review_full: My partner and I dined here last night after looking for a fancier place to have dinner in Madrid. We came across this place which seemed lovely and not too expensive compared to others we had looked at. We chose a table outside which despite being February, was surprisingly not cold at all! We were given menus quickly and the waiter made every effort to speak English for us as we don't speak Spanish.  The menu is varied with some of the dishes being a little overpriced in our opinion. Prior to receiving anything we ordered, we were treated to a small glass of Rose (sparkling wine), 2 little glasses of vegetable soup, cream cheese with toasted bread slices and baguette slices with tomato, tuna & peppers. All of this was on the house which was a lovely extra! My partner opted for the Black Pudding starter which he said was very different from the Black Pudding we have at home (Scotland) but was very tasty. I had the Ham and Mozzerella pie which was a little like an empanada, and was very nice. For our main courses, my partner had the ribs which he said were lovely and I had the Spaghetti Bolognese which was great. Again, after dinner we were brought a glass of mango smoothie and a raspberry compot each on the house. The meal was finished with a complimentary Ap√©ritif which was such a nice touch. My only grumble is that there appeared to be a large gathering of homeless people outside the restaurant, which wouldn't bother us however they started to come into the restaurant and ask for money. They were quickly escorted out by management however.  I'd definitely recommend this restaurant as it was lovely however some dishes are overpriced for what they are.

I had the ribs and they were delicious. There is a lot of "free" addons at the end with frozen yogurt and shots (but don't get caught out with the bread which is not complimentary which we discovered....(‚Ç¨5 at the end of our bill for bread that wasn't touched). Fantastic service by our waitress Stephanie who was exceptional at her job and I think she realised we were not happy with being stung on the deal at the start, but definitely made the experience better. All in all not a bad restaurant but not for the budget minded.

title_review: More than you could possibly ask for
review_preview: We were 4 people who incidentally dropped in to see if they had a vacant table. Fortunately they did. We quickly ordered our food and immediately we were being treated almost like royalty. Absolutely delicious pre-starters were served, the tapas, the food and the wines...
review_full: We were 4 people who incidentally dropped in to see if they had a vacant table. Fortunately they did. We quickly ordered our food and immediately we were being treated almost like royalty. Absolutely delicious pre-starters were served, the tapas, the food and the wines were all excellent and reasonably priced - even the vegetarian truffle risotto was juicy and tasty. If you like a fruity, well-balanced and rounded white wine with no acidity try the "Vinas de Anna" - excellent (comes in a fancy white bottle), and the TORO red wine wasn't bad either - rather good actually.. Service was promt and efficient with no annoying waiting time for the food. We were too full to have an after dinner sweet, but as we ordered coffee the co-waiter served a lovely panacotta and an absolutely fresh and mouthwatering mango smoothie. As we were about to go we were introduced to a nice, ice cold "limoncella" - maybe a trifle too sweet for some, but a nice finish to an excellent and lavish dinner. We will definitely come back to this place next time we are in Madrid and will recommend this restaurant to friends and family - and everybody else. It's absolutely worth a visit and is placed just opposite the opera in case you have problems finding it. Great experience not to be missed.

title_review: A JOY! A MUST! WE WILL RETURN!
review_preview: Usually we read a lot of TA reviews and hand pick places to eat. But last night (night 3 of a 3-night stay In Madrid) we took a short walk from our hotel near Teatro Real and found this restaurant. Unbelievably - 12 December -...
review_full: Usually we read a lot of TA reviews and hand pick places to eat. But last night (night 3 of a 3-night stay In Madrid) we took a short walk from our hotel near Teatro Real and found this restaurant. Unbelievably - 12 December - we could sit outside on the terrace. We were greeted with an on-the-house glass of cava roused (that is a first). Our meal was simple - excellent char-grilled sirloin (probably some of the best beef we have ever tasted) with a heap of mixed leaf and pine kernel salad, a bottle of the only "Madrid" red wine on the list (oomphy and fruity) and a shared dessert of home-made pedro ximenez ice cream. Bliss. But that wasn't all. On-the-house dessert tapas - a little mango smoothie and blueberries on sweet cream cheese and carafes (yes plural) of limoncello. Great service. Great food. Great location (view currently of the Christmas market and the back of Teatro Real). I could go on. But my enthusiasm must already be apparent. Eat at this restaurant on a visit to Seville.

You can choose your meal from a good collection of little restaurants and carry it over to a window seat with one of the best views in the city. The prices are very reasonable and the choices are extremely varied.  This is a different place to eat and view the beautiful city of Madrid.

We loved, will return, and recommend to everyone!!!!

review_full: I have had dinner and drinks at La Pescaderia twice in the last few months and have almost nothing bad to say about it! Both times I experienced great service, great ambiance and even better food. They have taken some great spanish classics and put just enough of a twist on them that you don't feel like you are getting the same old thing. Almost obligatory to make a reservation beforehand and, if you can, request a table in one of the sections closer to the front - the atmosphere is a lot better and you are saved from the view of the kitchen. I love the patatas bravas and tempura vegetables and definitely stick around for a cocktail after.

review_preview: After a hot day and long siesta, our family of four (mom dad and two teenaged girls) walked down to the Primark for shopping.  Luckily Google maps had this little spot listed.  We had already fallen into the tourist trap tapas bars and wanted something...
review_full: After a hot day and long siesta, our family of four (mom dad and two teenaged girls) walked down to the Primark for shopping. Luckily Google maps had this little spot listed. We had already fallen into the tourist trap tapas bars and wanted something that Madrile√±os would visit. This lovely place delivered BIG. We were greeted by a busy manager, who found us a table even with such a booming crowd. Beautiful red wine by the glass and ice cold cervesa for the adults and Coca Cola for the kids. The girls had fresh herby greek salad and the tav ble shared the tuna with tomato salad. We also had cod fritters with a wonderful sauce. We were given a basket of crusty bread to savor all of the sauces and dressings with. Cheesecake all around after was a wonderful treat. It was light and not too sweet but drizzled with a wonderful raspberry sauce. One of my daughters is ovo lacto pescaterian vegetarian and it can be challenging to find satisfying food for her outside the home. It is truly worth your while as a visitor to travel off the main roads a bit. For a two-block walk from Gran Via we were rewarded heartily. Thank you to our beautiful host and waitress and cooks for a great family meal.

review_preview: Of all the El Corte Ingles food courts that I visited this was by far the most impressive. A huge array of different gastronomic experiences with an amazing outside roof terrace (smoking allowed).  My favourite was the lovely wine and cheese merchants by the doors...
review_full: Of all the El Corte Ingles food courts that I visited this was by far the most impressive. A huge array of different gastronomic experiences with an amazing outside roof terrace (smoking allowed). My favourite was the lovely wine and cheese merchants by the doors to the terrace. Very reasonable and very palatable glasses of wine, each served with a bowl of olives, cheese or jamon. Such a lovely experience we went back the following day. They also serve some gourmet snacks, tapas and oysters.  Other choices on the floor range from burgers to Mexican to ice cream to cakes.  Such fantastic quality from a run of the mill department store.  Be aware that the toilets by the lift on this floor are too small and the queue will be long. Save time and make the trip down a floor or two to use some empty ones and be back much quicker

title_review: Go for the view and a tasty bite between the Palace and the Prado
review_preview: Everyone probably ends up, at some point, in one of the many El Corte Ingles locations around Spain: if you're going to go to one in Madrid, I would make this the one because of the Gourmet Experience on the 9th floor.There are those...
review_full: Everyone probably ends up, at some point, in one of the many El Corte Ingles locations around Spain: if you're going to go to one in Madrid, I would make this the one because of the Gourmet Experience on the 9th floor. There are those who will say El Corte Ingles is just a department store -- and of course, it is. But they have some clever "extras" (take your passport & get a 10% off voucher for the day!) After you've wandered around for a bit, head to the 9th floor where the Gourmet Experience offers a cluster of eatery options from pintxos (small plates) to pasta to sushi to burgers to freshly shaved jamon iberico, to pastries, etc (all "gourmet" of course.) The pintxos I got were excellent: fresh, tasty, imaginative. A local Madrileno businessman sitting at the counter recommended his favorite wine to go with the seafood pintxos I picked - all I can say is I wish I'd written it down! The Gourmet Experience is also a great place to pick up presents for your favorite "foodie" back home (especially if this is your last stop and you're running out of time), but the best thing about it (for me) were the fantastic views from the wrap-around deck. The food and drink are NOT cheap (nor expensive - just don't think "food court" or "snack bar" -- these are far better and nicer than that!).  You'll find better deals in lots of places around Madrid. But like most big cities, some places offer more than just food -- and you pay for "experience" as much as the food/drink. The Gourmet Experience at El Corte Ingles is a fun stop -- and convenient to many of the places you'll probably be visiting in Madrid. In fact, if one of you wants to shop and the other needs a glass of wine -- this may be the best choice in town.

review_preview: What an exciting find, a classy food market on top of one of the biggest department stores in Spain. What a disappointment, to find that the food was below par.Lovely atmosphere, fabulous view of the city's rooftops and iconic churches, but don't bother with...
review_full: What an exciting find, a classy food market on top of one of the biggest department stores in Spain. What a disappointment, to find that the food was below par. Lovely atmosphere, fabulous view of the city's rooftops and iconic churches, but don't bother with the food from the Mexican outlet. The nachos were the only good part of the meal. The enchiladas were tasteless, the ham and cheese quesadillas were like ham and cheese toasties. Everything was served with a green sauce which was unidentifiable and bland. Lovely idea, poorly executed. Very disappointed.

review_preview: This restaurant got great reviews on YELP. I went here with my companion and immediately liked the good vibe.  We did not have a reservation, but arrived before 9:00 and got a nice table.  It filled up by 10:00 and they were turning people away....
review_full: This restaurant got great reviews on YELP. I went here with my companion and immediately liked the good vibe. We did not have a reservation, but arrived before 9:00 and got a nice table. It filled up by 10:00 and they were turning people away. I had one of the top 5 meals of my life! The selections include mostly fish/shellfish that are prepared with interesting ingredients. I had the grilled shrimp with avocado and mango and my companion had the salmon. Both were perfectly prepared and delicious. We started out our meal with a couple tapas and each ordered a different salad. We topped off our meal with desserts of carrot cake and chocolate banana cake. We each had wine and the bill was around $70.00e. I would not hesitate to give this restaurant my highest accolades.

review_preview: What a delicious way to start your day!  Open earlier than most places in Madrid (7:30AM), this place gets a lot of visits by locals for cafe, freshly-squeezed orange juice (for 1.90E, so good!) and, of course, for churros con chocolat, or churros and some...
review_full: What a delicious way to start your day! Open earlier than most places in Madrid (7:30AM), this place gets a lot of visits by locals for cafe, freshly-squeezed orange juice (for 1.90E, so good!) and, of course, for churros con chocolat, or churros and some lovely melted chocolate to dip in. Wait service is good; they don't speak much English but are very friendly. The menu has a lot of pictures you can point at. Also, they bring around various treats at times for sampling; I think they're free, because they didn't charge us for it. At a later date, we had one of their sandwiches with tuna and vegetables which was very good, as well as tea from their large tea menu. The teas were a bit on the pricier side and were loose-leaf, and lots of little leaves would escape to the tea.

review_preview: After doing a lot of intensive research, we decided to have our requisite churros and chocolate in Madrid here rather than at San Gines. The owner mixes and fries the churros on the spot and they are crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside,...
review_full: After doing a lot of intensive research, we decided to have our requisite churros and chocolate in Madrid here rather than at San Gines. The owner mixes and fries the churros on the spot and they are crisp on the outside, chewy on the inside, with a slight saltiness. The dipping chocolate is smooth, of the right consistency, and not too sweet. It was more than enough for us to have one cup of chocolate, an order of smaller churros and larger porras. Often when we have dessert, we find our mouths have an aftertaste of sugar. Not so here. The desserts are perfectly sweetened, so even though we ate churros and porras with chocolate, a frappe and a complimentary cookie afterwards--more sweets than we normally would have--we felt good afterwards. The owner and assistant were quite affable and friendly, and the place was filled with Madrid locals having a family celebration. What more could one ask for as an authentic travel experience?

title_review: Worst dining experience in a long time
review_preview: I live in Madrid and eat out regularly.This is the worst service and food I have ever received. I'm actually sitting in the restaurant now typing this as I'm so angry.We arrived at 2pm, and ordered starters which arrived 20 mins later. No...
review_full: I live in Madrid and eat out regularly. This is the worst service and food I have ever received. I'm actually sitting in the restaurant now typing this as I'm so angry. We arrived at 2pm, and ordered starters which arrived 20 mins later. No problems there. Then we waited 45 further minutes for the second course to arrive. Despite asking several times, we got told by the waitress "look it's not my fault". Great service. Then three of the four meals arrived. However the waitress had no idea what the different types of burgers were. To make matters worse, one of the burgers was meant to be "well done", I can only describe it as "having a heartbeat". Naturally, it was sent back. 20 minutes later we were still two burgers down, then they arrived. Sadly the burger we sent back was still completely raw when it returned. So poor. I won't return here, poor service, clueless staff, long waiting times, and cold food. Let's not forget the inability of staff to accept culpability. Dont waste your time and don't eat here. That's my advice.

title_review: Great food, great atmosphere, nice people but...
review_preview: The food was excellent.  The people were nice, the vibe was cool and fun.  We went there twice and would actually rate this 4 stars.    Two things made this a three though.  The first was that the sangria we ordered was watered down and was,...
review_full: The food was excellent. The people were nice, the vibe was cool and fun. We went there twice and would actually rate this 4 stars. Two things made this a three though. The first was that the sangria we ordered was watered down and was, to say the least, average. Nonetheless, it was late at night when we arrived so we ordered our food since we were really hungry and drank. Then comes the second thing. It was last call for food orders as the kitchen was closing. Hate to say anything negative about the place but the kitchen was being cleaned with gloved hands, which was great, but the same gloved hands were used to handle the last food orders. Soap and clean, handle food, then soaped and cleaned again. From our vantage point we just looked in disbelief. Be that as it may, we went there much earlier before closing time and had excellent food again and this time, really good sangria. Why did we go back? The place was next door to our hotel, we were tired and hungry. And it was early enough at night that we surely would not need to order for last call. If not for these two things, 4 stars.

title_review: A must visit place if u r in Madrid.
