review_full: Liked the vibe of this place. We came across this place walking down Gran Via and decided to visit it for dinner one night. It's a huge place with different restaurant areas within once u enter.. the outer area is the tapas bar while the inside restaurant is more of a fine-dine place. We sat by the bar and ordered tapas while sipping on their in-house red wine collection..good food and value for money is bang on. We liked the place so much that we went to this place again before we left from Madrid and had a good meal! Must-try their ham,brie and asparagus toast, tomato and garlic bread, squid-prawn & ham skewers and tomato & garlic bread with iberico ham plate. The last one was the best we ever had.. a perfect way to end a Spanish trip with a Spanish meal.

review_preview: We had a reservation and were promptly seated at 8:30 p.m., along with all of the other Americans, upstairs behind the bar (--there was not a Spaniard in the whole room--just tourists). Service was poor--we wanted to order a chardonnay, but our very junior server...
review_full: We had a reservation and were promptly seated at 8:30 p.m., along with all of the other Americans, upstairs behind the bar (--there was not a Spaniard in the whole room--just tourists). Service was poor--we wanted to order a chardonnay, but our very junior server wasn't aware of what wine might be closest to our preference and he asked the main waiter--the waiter in black--who abruptly responded "none," without offering an alternative (there were 3 white wines on the wine list). Once ordered, they never once poured the wine for us. The tapas were mediocre, salad was pedestrian, and the steaks (my husband and daughter ordered two different ones) and lamb were terrible (all of the meat was grisly, fatty, and nearly inedible). One steak came with the green peppers commonly served at tapas restaurants; we never tasted poor peppers until we went to Mercado de la Reina--they were cold and limp. A note to anyone reading all the 5 star TripAdvisor reviews for this restaurant: NOTE HOW MANY ARE PAID SPONSORSHIPS from the restaurant. I missed that little line, and find those reviews deceiving. There are many great restaurants in Madrid. This is not one of them.

review_full: Asador Imanol Gourmet Experience Gran Via-Callao is one the the three Basque restaurants by the same Asador Imanol group in Madrid. review_preview: New to Madrid last year, the proprietor of my hotel recommended we try Chocolat for chocolat con churros.  We fell in love with the place the first time we visited.  The food was good and the service was great, the place was spotless, including the...
review_full: New to Madrid last year, the proprietor of my hotel recommended we try Chocolat for chocolat con churros. We fell in love with the place the first time we visited. The food was good and the service was great, the place was spotless, including the bathroom area. As some reviewers have mentioned, the 'porros' are very greasy and I avoided them. The chocolate con churros was delicious and was very good compared with others I had tried in other cities in Spain. Upon my return to Madrid this year, I headed back to Chocolat and had breakfast there most days. It was a nice and relaxing start to the day to have a good coffee, a bite to eat, good service and a friendly atmosphere while getting on the Wifi to plan my day or catch up on emails. It is a small cafe and gets busy with locals and visitors. Be sure to have a glass of the fresh orange juice. I tried a few different things on the menu and all were good. I didn't have any complaints about the food. The prices were very reasonable and the offer of a free sweet after the meal was a nice touch. Location is good too, very near the Prado and about a 15 minute walk to the Atoche train station and Reina Sofia Museum. When I return to Madrid, I'll be stopping by Chocolat to get my day started.

title_review: My favorite place in Spain.  6 Stars.
review_preview: We found this place by happenstance wandering through one of the older sections of Madrid.  I loved it so much we went back three more times in a week.This place makes its own chocolate, and the churros con chocolate are amazing.  The best I...
review_full: We found this place by happenstance wandering through one of the older sections of Madrid. I loved it so much we went back three more times in a week. This place makes its own chocolate, and the churros con chocolate are amazing. The best I had. This was definitely a place for locals, as lots came in and out for breakfsat every morning. The waitstaff was super nice. Our waiter that we had most days was exceptionally nice. They spoke a bit of English, and appreciated my attempts to communicate in Spanish. Later on, we went on a food tour with a local and he told us he likes to take tours there because it's one of his favorite places. The coffee is also very good, even for Madrid where all of the coffee is delicious. They also had good ham and tomato tostadas, and a variety of cakes and torts. I want to go back to Madrid anyway, but I wish I could visit this place every morning.

I don't understand why the reviews here are any good but we really felt like TripAdvisor fooled us this time.

title_review: More than just food. Don't miss it.
review_preview: This food court is located in the top floor of the Corte Ingles department store.  It features a great view of Madrid including a window where you can take a selfie with the Gran Via behind you.  The other windows have crosshairs that point to...
review_full: This food court is located in the top floor of the Corte Ingles department store. It features a great view of Madrid including a window where you can take a selfie with the Gran Via behind you. The other windows have crosshairs that point to many of the city's highlights. It's worthwhile visiting for breakfast, lunch, dinner or late drinks. The food court offers gourmet quality foods including Japanese, Chinese, Mexican, US, Italian, Spanish as well as various other dishes. Everything we tried was excellent.  The prices are well......European.  The store itself is worth visiting, they offer everything from a swiss knife to upscale electronics, a travel agency, cellphone operators, you name it.

title_review: Great place to try chocolate con churros
review_preview: One of the Madrile√±o specialties is chocolate con churros, which is exactly what it sounds like: churros and hot, thick dipping chocolate. It's eaten either as a dessert or as breakfast (Spaniards eat really sweet breakfasts apparently). One of the best places to get it...
review_full: One of the Madrile√±o specialties is chocolate con churros, which is exactly what it sounds like: churros and hot, thick dipping chocolate. It's eaten either as a dessert or as breakfast (Spaniards eat really sweet breakfasts apparently). One of the best places to get it is Chocolat. For ‚Ç¨3.50, you get 4 big churros and a cup of chocolate to dip them in. It's hard to go wrong with this combination, and it's one of the few foods that actually originated in Madrid. Definitely worth trying if you're visiting Madrid.

title_review: Great view, great selection of food.
review_preview: Spent two days and nights in Madrid and visited The Gourmet Experience both nights.  Centrally located, easy to get to, interesting choices in an upscale environment.  Nice wrap around deck with city views, where you can take your food gatherings and have a nosh while...
review_full: Spent two days and nights in Madrid and visited The Gourmet Experience both nights. Centrally located, easy to get to, interesting choices in an upscale environment. Nice wrap around deck with city views, where you can take your food gatherings and have a nosh while enjoying the sunset. It's loud, and can be crowded, but worth it just to see what's what with the food. You can certainly score tapas at a lower price point, but it would be hard to find this much variety in the same amount of space, with a gourmet market attached. If nothing else, go for a coffee or a wine tasting and enjoy the view.

title_review: Gastro Emporium with a superlative view
review_preview: The Gourmet Experience sits atop El Corte Ingl√©s, a department store,  at the Plaza de Callao. Located on the 9th floor, this chic marketplace offers a wide array of gourmet delicacies and eateries where one can sample a broad range of cuisines: artisan breads, Dim...
review_full: The Gourmet Experience sits atop El Corte Ingl√©s, a department store, at the Plaza de Callao. Located on the 9th floor, this chic marketplace offers a wide array of gourmet delicacies and eateries where one can sample a broad range of cuisines: artisan breads, Dim Sum, razor clams, hamburgers, Macarons, and gelati. It is a feast for foodies and visually delightful for the tourist. The bar in the center serves awesome cocktails. Throughout this space one finds tables and booths, some with wonderful windows with view of Madrid. The outside terrace, when the weather cooperates, offers a nice intimate place to view the city, especially the iconic Schweppes Building with its distinctive signage. Night is the best time to enjoy the illuminated sign. And a great place for people watching too. I found it somewhat pushy, jumpy, and very crowded to really enjoy. My suggestion is to go late, about 90 minutes before closing when there are more tables and booths open, and the food stands are less crowded. I tried that tactic, and the experience was stellar and very convivial.

review_preview: El Corte Ingles is a the largest department store chain in Spain. There are many locations all over the country, and many within Madrid. The Callao location, walking distance from Sol, has a 9th Gourmet Experience. The Gourmet Experience is is a collection of high...
review_full: El Corte Ingles is a the largest department store chain in Spain. There are many locations all over the country, and many within Madrid. The Callao location, walking distance from Sol, has a 9th Gourmet Experience. The Gourmet Experience is is a collection of high quality mini restaurants in a single floor--this should not be called a food court as that term evokes a sense of crappy mall food typically found here in the US. These are all very good stand alone restaurants really, serving various cuisines fresh cooked to order. We particularly enjoyed the spanish local cuisine restaurant for lunch twice and the gelateria was excellent. The prices are a bit higher, but the quality is superior. I wish the 9th floor were larger with more center floor general seating, as seating can be excessively challenging to get. Each restaurant has very small dedicated seating in their respectively areas. There is also shopping dedicated to finer wines and spirits and fine packaged food etc. The views are lovely.

review_full: This place is so well located to hang around in town, you have to lift up to the top of the shopping centre (9th floor) and will get views of Madrid. BUT, take care in coming with time because the tables near the window are little. Anyway, all around the space are a lot of spots where you can sit and enjoy food from different places. There is a mexican place where the music is kind of loud, during the weeking more, but if you don't want noise you just don't seat in that square. Is not cheap, but is affordable, and a must go even if you are a resident. There is a terrace, but views there are not that good as inside. Also, you have a GOURMET selection with food separated from a lot of different countries. If you are a foreigner, I recommend you to take a look and then go down to the supermarket in the same building to compare prizes, as here, in gourmet experience, the shop is kind of expensive. On the other hand you can find things more nice for a present or more strange. It reminds me to the top floor of the shopping centre of brands placed in Milan, called ''La renaissenza'' or something similar, where you can also see the Duomo.

title_review: Good choices - Great setting for something casual

review_full: This is an upscale food court, so really just for casual fare. There are many choices here, but we went to a counter that also sells smoked fish and a range of cheeses. We had a cheese plate and a plate of smoked salmon for lunch, along with a nice glass of cava. The smoked salmon was the best we had in Madrid, and we had it in many places. But buy your meal at any place, take it out to the terrace, then enjoy the food and your views over the Palacio Real and more.

title_review: Very good food and impressive views
review_preview: We tried food from 3 of the outlets in this food hall on the 9th floor of El Corte Ingles in Madrid.1. Oyster bar - very fresh tasty oysters and Laurent Perrier champagne, the crisp dry taste complimented them perfectly. Excellent service as well....
review_full: We tried food from 3 of the outlets in this food hall on the 9th floor of El Corte Ingles in Madrid. 1. Oyster bar - very fresh tasty oysters and Laurent Perrier champagne, the crisp dry taste complimented them perfectly. Excellent service as well. 2. Gourmet burger bar - it was starting to get busy so there was a wait for our burgers but they were made with succulent flavoursome beef and served medium rare as requested. One of the better burgers I've had. 3. Macaroon and coffee shop - the pistachio macaroons filled with a divine ice cream were amazing, highly recommended. The views from the terrace are worth seeing, it was unusually quite cloudy during our visit though. The prices here are well above average but you do get good quality food, a great view, and the atmosphere is buzzing.

title_review: Spain, wines, tapas but only one Dis Tinto......
review_preview: Imagine you visit Madrid, imagine you consider yourself a tourist, imagine walking with a map not having a clue where the Prado is and on top, being hungry...So you might end up at Duque de Medicinali, walking by a very small door, hiding Dis Tinto,...
review_full: Imagine you visit Madrid, imagine you consider yourself a tourist, imagine walking with a map not having a clue where the Prado is and on top, being hungry...So you might end up at Duque de Medicinali, walking by a very small door, hiding Dis Tinto, tiny tiny bar, truly not special from outside. Inside, Ivan, beard man, smile from there to Barcelona, happy man but probably the most experienced wine seller ever met in my life. It seems also co-owner of the place along with his cousin, Angel, also there. Both men, only there to please the customer, offering small bites, tapas with a twist but especially wines with many twists from the most diverse regions of Spain. Tenerife, Extremadura, Galicia, all passed the lunch accompanied by grilled squid, bull tail (oh yes) and delicious olives. So beard man and Angel, you surprised me, you delighted me, you are probably one of the best experiences ever in Madrid so here we go.........Michelin star you should get and if not.....lot's of customers on top.

title_review: Outstanding, among a lot of excellent bar/restaurants
review_preview: Everyone goes off the main tourist routes in Madrid. we did, found this bar/restaurant and went every day. Why? Because the Staff were so welcoming. The place was busy with locals/people on lunch breaks and some tourists. everyone fitted in. The atmosphere was great. But...
review_full: Everyone goes off the main tourist routes in Madrid. we did, found this bar/restaurant and went every day. Why? Because the Staff were so welcoming. The place was busy with locals/people on lunch breaks and some tourists. everyone fitted in. The atmosphere was great. But most of all, the food was superb. Everything freshly cooked, almost in front of you. We had, over the few days: Tortilla, Croqettes, Casserole of the day, soup, sardines, burger, bread, olives, cheeseboard. And everything was well cooked and presented. The vino Tinto and Vino Blanco were excellent. For anyone visiting the Prado and the various locations nearby this place is easily the best place you can choose. Never more than 25 Euros per couple for outstanding service, excellent food and a very pleasant environment.

title_review: Top quality food with great views to boot
review_preview: This is one of my go-to places when family and friends are visiting Madrid. At the gourmet experience you have access to a selection of top-quality restaurants (often with long reservation lists at their main venues) without the need to book. A great selection of...
review_full: This is one of my go-to places when family and friends are visiting Madrid. At the gourmet experience you have access to a selection of top-quality restaurants (often with long reservation lists at their main venues) without the need to book.  A great selection of world cuisines to suit all tastes. Tables are available within the pop-up restaurants or in the central dining area which allows group members to choose different restaurants whilst eating together. Try to grab a table on the exterior terraza to get views of Gran Via! Prices aren't extortionate but be prepared to pay above average prices for Madrid. The quality of food here is well worth the extra euros!

title_review: This place will soon become too small ...... EXCELLENCE and ALEGRIA
review_preview: Scarce are the places I have visited based on a recommendation from colleague foodies or friends. Even stranger is the fact I would agree to their opinion. Madrid, capital of Spain and by far one of the most pleasant places on earth for city trips,...
review_full: Scarce are the places I have visited based on a recommendation from colleague foodies or friends. Even stranger is the fact I would agree to their opinion. Madrid, capital of Spain and by far one of the most pleasant places on earth for city trips, has now a little precious diamond, walking distance from Sol (official city centre) where two cousins apparently teamed up with a great chef to deliver what I call an amazing interpretation of the Spanish cuisine. No agar agar, gellification, spherization (not sure this is a word), nitrogen shots or any cookoo techniques being deployed by Adria and friends but clean techniques with good products and a wine pairing you have never experienced before. These guys have an ideal team, know their business, listen to their customers, serve them like kings and remain affordable. Off course, do not expect tapas for one euro, meals for 10 eur. you are a foodie, not a simple backpack tourist. You expect to be delighted, I can assure you, you will. Grilled octopus on a creamy risotto, bull's tail (the real tail) with truffel puree amongst others. Wines from Tenerife and the unappreciated bodegas resalte to complete the picture. I was there, I saw and I want to go back.

title_review: Attractive bar, wonderful food, THE best olives . . .
review_preview: We just called in here for a drink one day.  To accompany our drinks, we were given a bowl of olives which we demolished in record quick time.  Bizarrely, to us at least, they had slices of carrot in the marinade but you will just...
review_full: We just called in here for a drink one day. To accompany our drinks, we were given a bowl of olives which we demolished in record quick time. Bizarrely, to us at least, they had slices of carrot in the marinade but you will just have to check them out for yourselves to find out how good they are. So delicious! Later, we were given some crackers filled with Russian salad. Not some sloppy mayo with bits of cold vegetable in - but a substantial potato salad (ok, yes, probably with bits of cold vegetable) full of flavour. Again, absolutely delicious. We met up in this bar again after visiting The Prado on our last day, initially just for a drink. Checking our watches to make sure we could still be back at the hotel in time for the taxi to the airport, we ended up ordering from the menu and eating in the small dining area at the rear of the bar. We opted to share several dishes and each dish we sampled was wonderful. If you like quality food served in a contemporary bar setting, give this place a try.

title_review: Sit at the bar, but go early!

review_full: One of the nicer tapas places, right on Gran Via. Do try to get there early so you can sit at the bar (‚Äúearly‚Äù meaning around 7PM). Get a hightop table or sit right at the bar, order some pinchos or small plates, enjoy some wine or Cruzcampo, and I guarantee you‚Äôll have a good time. The bar seemed to be the most popular hangout, with it getting pretty crowded by 8-9PM, especially on Thursday-Saturday nights. My friends got the burgers, which they said were okay. Most of the other tapas (the octopus, the pulgas, etc) were pretty good, but we kept coming back for this specific tapa: The WILD MUSHROOM, CARAMELIZED ONION, AND GOAT CHEESE PINCHO. So amazing!! Heaven on a small slice of baguette.

title_review: Good ambience and concept, bad food
review_preview: This place capitalises on the deco and the area they are in (Chueca, Gran via). The food they give is nothing special: the way it is cooked and presented is OK, but the quality is too low for the expectation (their marketing is around quaility...
review_full: This place capitalises on the deco and the area they are in (Chueca, Gran via). The food they give is nothing special: the way it is cooked and presented is OK, but the quality is too low for the expectation (their marketing is around quaility food from the market) The service is not very good (but this is expected, as the place is quite crowded), and the sitting area is 'canteen style'.. Do not expect to have any privacy in your lunch/dinner as it is impossible not to hear everything the people are discussing around you: there are long tables were everyone sits elbow to elbow or individual tables for 2/4 people with 2cms distance between each other. Another point is that the place is quite expensive for what you get! I shared 4 tapas/raciones plus a couple of glassses of wine, and I paid 36 eur! I will not come back to this place and would not recommend either... there are many better places to eat in the area.

review_preview: We had a fabulous dinner at this restaurant that was recommended to us by our hotel's concierge. It is not a tourist restaurant and so was empty when we arrived at 8 pm( but began to fill with Spaniards after 10). We decided to splurge...
review_full: We had a fabulous dinner at this restaurant that was recommended to us by our hotel's concierge. It is not a tourist restaurant and so was empty when we arrived at 8 pm( but began to fill with Spaniards after 10). We decided to splurge and ordered the 70 euro per person tasting menu. The meal consisted of 7-8 inventive courses each of which was artistically presented and so yummy. Dishes included a white asparagus appetizer, monkfish, beef and much much more.Each was served with exquisite sauces. The deserts were also fabulous. One was a mango cream within a egg shaped crust and another was a take-off on a cafe au lait. We were treated to a small peppery gin and tonic at the end of this extravaganza. We highly recommend this restaurant for a fine dining experience!!

title_review: Buzz, buzz, buzz - in with the (local) crowd
review_preview: We came here for a light supper of typical tapas, and we were not disappointed - the Mercado de la Reina lived up to its billing as a buzzy and friendly place, with good food.  It took a little bit of time to sit down...
review_full: We came here for a light supper of typical tapas, and we were not disappointed - the Mercado de la Reina lived up to its billing as a buzzy and friendly place, with good food. It took a little bit of time to sit down - the tapas tables are not bookable, so you have to wait for someone to leave, but in a short time we were seated at an interesting table arranged around a tree. The food and drink order was very quickly fulfilled, though we had to go to the bar to pick it up, and the food was absolutely delicious - each plateful tasty and just sufficient! The atmosphere was really full of chatter, with lots of locals as well as tourists - people watching definitely on the cards! I would definitely return, although perhaps this time to sit down and eat more formally.

review_preview: Read some good reviews, and thought it seemed a nice spot for a quiet dinner for two. The pictures don't deceive, and the space is beautiful, if not very small. The service was adequate, our waitress humoring us with our horrendous language skills. The host...
review_full: Read some good reviews, and thought it seemed a nice spot for a quiet dinner for two. The pictures don't deceive, and the space is beautiful, if not very small.  The service was adequate, our waitress humoring us with our horrendous language skills. The host however, who came to actually take the order, was not interested in hospitality, and was rather curt. They delivered an amuse bouche, which was essentially a poached egg, in a mayonnaise based sauce. We enjoyed it, and looked forward to the rest of our meal.  Until it came. Our appetizers were both similarly mayonnaise - sauced. Forgive me for not remembering exactly what they were, but my lack of memory may be due to the forgettable nature of the dishes. My wife ordered a risotto for her entree, and when it arrived, it became the only non mayonnaise based sauce dish on the table for the evening, as my fish dish, advertised as having a red chili sauce, was covered in... Wait for it... Another mayonnaise based sauce. At this point I realized that perhaps a warning from the host as we ordered would've been appropriate.  Mayonnaise. It's been around for hundreds of years. Apparently though, the chef on duty the night we were there only recently discovered it. Perhaps earlier that day. It seemed like an off night, and there were hints of quality scattered through the evening (my wife's risotto being quite good,) but we will clearly not be returning.

Will deffinetly be back when I am back in Madrid

title_review: A merigue for a birthday cake!
review_preview: We made reservations for dinner at La Bien Aparecida, a superb restaurant with an excellent wine list.   We chose Paletilla de Cordero, an outstanding Godello white with a lemony bouquet.  The food was up-to-date Spanish varying from exquisite pre-appetizer amuse-bouche of miniature bocadillos of steak...
review_full: We made reservations for dinner at La Bien Aparecida, a superb restaurant with an excellent wine list. We chose Paletilla de Cordero, an outstanding Godello white with a lemony bouquet. The food was up-to-date Spanish varying from exquisite pre-appetizer amuse-bouche of miniature bocadillos of steak tartar, light and fluffy ham croquetas, and mussels in a silver colored coating. We joined these with a lovely cava. Next we had an anchovy and red pepper lasagna which was vertically arranged without pasta. The meal progressed to a casserole Madrile√±o style for me, which was a mixture of various kinds of variety meats, except liver and kidneys, with small pieces of beef in a thickened tomato broth. My husband had a monkfish filet which was artfully and exquisitely plated and tender, unlike any monkfish he has had anywhere before. A friend had lamb shoulder chops with a sweet sauce. Dessert was the pi√®ce de r√©sistance. To celebrate John's birthday our friend ordered a meringue over a lemon tart with fresh mango--and a candle. To accompany this we had a chocolate egg with a hard shell filled with runny fudge. The finishing touch, Madrile√±o style, was a round of light gin and tonics with lemon peel and a red berry. G &T's are the fashion in Madrid to finish excellent meals.

title_review: McDonald's would have been better...worst restaurant experience ever
review_preview: I was so disappointed in this restaurant, and angered at the service. We tried to get in one night, but it was full. We made a reservation for next evening, trekked to the restaurant, again, because of a decent review in Lonely Planet, and a...
review_full: I was so disappointed in this restaurant, and angered at the service. We tried to get in one night, but it was full. We made a reservation for next evening, trekked to the restaurant, again, because of a decent review in Lonely Planet, and a recommendation by an owner's friend. HOWEVER, we were given (bad) food we did not order, and they insisted we did...e.g., we ordered a pork stew with mashed potatoes, and got a blood pudding with fried eggs on bad french fries (which they had tried to pawn off on neighboring americans who had ordered sirloin). Some fatty beef dish was pawned off as the pork stew - and it was clearly beef! with a vile looking curd of a sauce. My "secret loin" was so secret, they kept it in the refrigerator without re-heating the both over and undercooked slabs of pork before serving. One saving grace was the very good roasted asparagus, but the other apps never came until we reminded them at entree serving, which was LITERALLY 1.5 hours after we ordered. When trying to reconcile this, they insisted we were wrong, had to argue! and it took three printings of the bill to get it to reflect what we actually sort of ate. They even charged us an extra person for bread and for an extra bottle of water: TWICE! The table next to us were lovely people from Ireland, and they too, had a similar experience with entrees coming out wrong, and the remainders over half an hour after their dinner partners were eating. Their neighbors also got their meals incorrectly. I was shocked. It really felt like we were intentionally were ignored all night. They've all perfected the "I don't see you" of obnoxious waiters. We had heard you can't get a bad meal in Madrid. Sadly, that was proved terribly wrong.

The staff was friendly and I highly recommend this place.

review_full: La Bien Aparecida is in the top ten restaurants of Madrid in every respect: quality of food, variety of drinking alternatives and professionalism of it's staff. Centrally located at Calle Jorge Juan, a few steps from Serrano, La Bien Aparecida has a modern design in a classical style. Customers are offered a delicious egg with fresh tuna (bonito) appetizer. We ordered as a an opener a magnificent foie done to perfection; and the main courses of fish and pork were a delight. All were washed down with an excellent and not expensive bottle of Luis Ca√±as Rioja. We will definitely return to La Bien Aparecida whenever we travel to Madrid.

review_preview: My friend and I had dinner at La Bien Aparecida on the last night of our short break in Madrid. The restaurant had been recommended to us by a friend of a friend who was in fact Spanish and lived in the city.  We had...
review_full: My friend and I had dinner at La Bien Aparecida on the last night of our short break in Madrid. The restaurant had been recommended to us by a friend of a friend who was in fact Spanish and lived in the city. We had a table booked for 8pm which I believe was the time they started serving dinner. The food was delicious and I would have given a five star rating if I was just rating food but I have never in my life experienced such rushed service to the point of rudeness. We were given an amuse-bouche which was very pleasant and the second we put down our cutlery the plates were whipped away and our starters were served. We joked amongst ourselves saying that we hoped the main course wasn‚Äôt served up so quickly but alas I had barely put my fork down when these dishes were cleared away and lo and behold our main courses arrived. We were shocked and a little disappointed as we had wanted to savour our starters and let the food go down a little before eating our main courses. We also had a lovely bottle of wine to enjoy. We almost wanted to send the food back but didn‚Äôt want to risk getting it back re-heated so instead I called over a member of staff to say that we were very disappointed to be so rushed with our food. She apologised and left us to our meal. As mentioned before the food itself was extremely good but the overall experience was not enjoyable because of the rushed service. Also we were served by many different members of staff so they possibly were unaware of how quickly we were being served. After our main courses a dessert menu was thrust into our hands immediately the plates were cleared away and by this time I had had enough and asked to be left alone. We slowly enjoyed the rest of our wine and as a matter of principle did not order dessert as we were unhappy with our experience. We may have just been unlucky but surely someone knew how quickly we were being served up our food? I like to feel I am a fair person so wouldn‚Äôt say don‚Äôt come here as it was a lovely restaurant and the food was very good but it was such a shame we felt so rushed through the courses. I have completed this review in the hope that The Management will speak to staff/chefs to avoid this happening in future. All our dishes were served within 40 minutes of arriving.

title_review: STYLISH SPANISH CUISINE IN AN EYE CATCHING SETTING
review_preview: This restaurant caught our eye first when it was listed in Travel & Leisure as one of 2018's recommended restaurants.  We made reservations before our trip directly on its website easily.  It's located on the north side of Retiro Park, so we took a taxi...
review_full: This restaurant caught our eye first when it was listed in Travel & Leisure as one of 2018's recommended restaurants. We made reservations before our trip directly on its website easily. It's located on the north side of Retiro Park, so we took a taxi from our hotel. If your hotel (visitor) is located near Plaza Mayor or Santa Ana, then you will need to take a cab.  Upon arrival, we were impressed with its sense of arrival. There were tables set outside for those who preferred. However, it was much too hot for us (even in late September) to do so. We were seated immediately upstairs. They have a downstairs as well, so they have plenty of seating. While walking to our table and once seated, we really admired the decor and design of the restaurant. You must pay attention to the wall decor and look for the gold knives, forks, spoons which from a distance simply look like fancy decorations. Up close, you'll see what I mean, so please look for this. It was quite creative and whimsical. Great design application. We were equally impressed with the lighting and light fixtures. It reminded us of another restaurant in New York City, called Le Coucou in lower Manhatten.  We were presented with a nice, large menu with a number of intersting items. My wife wanted to order some items off the menu, and our server was more than happy to accommodate us. This flexibility is so important to us and happy to see they could do this, unlike some other restaurants. My wife did order a "Mixta Ensalada" (mixed salad). I ordered the "La Purrusalda" (homemade pasta) as a hot starter (delicious) from the menu. In addition, my wife ordered the Free-range chicken rice on the menu, and I ordered a house special: Lomo de Rape Asado (roasted monkfish loin) as a main entree. Along with this, we enjoyed a great dessert on the menu: Sorpresa de Chocolate (chocolate surprise with citrus eucalyptus plus 70% cocoa ice cream (yum)! I should also point out that they also have a large and short menu available at a fixed price. We didn't try this.  The only initial issue we had was that our initial server did not speak enough English to understand us, and we didn't speak enough Spanish. Once this was identified, we quickly had another server who did.  So, we highly recommend this restaurant while in Madrid.

review_preview: In the chic Salamanca district, the restaurant done in modern "farmhouse" is a delight for the eyes. The outdoor tables, even in January are warm and romantic (though we did not choose this option. The food is Spanish modern and everything our family of five...
review_full: In the chic Salamanca district, the restaurant done in modern "farmhouse" is a delight for the eyes. The outdoor tables, even in January are warm and romantic (though we did not choose this option. The food is Spanish modern and everything our family of five tasted was a nearly perfect creation. We particularly enjoyed the wild clams from Sarten, the white gazpacho and the croquettes as appetizers. For main courses, the Hake in green sauce, with clams and white asparagus was a perfectly balanced dish, while the beef burgundy served in a Staub ceramic pot could easily stand up to any version in Paris. Rice dishes were also expertly prepared. Desserts were outstanding -- Tart Tatin, Chocolate volcano surprise with eucalyptus citric and 70% cacao chocolate ice cream were both delightful and creative. Service was correct and professional, but the waiters were a bit "glum" unlike so many restaurants in Madrid where the wait staffs are full of life and joy. Smile a bit and don't be so robotic

title_review: The best restaurant during this trip
review_preview: We entered this restaurant by chance, after some shopping in the district - Prada staff suggested us to walk along this street, and this was the first restaurant we saw, as well as the one to grab our attention.We were taken to a table...
review_full: We entered this restaurant by chance, after some shopping in the district - Prada staff suggested us to walk along this street, and this was the first restaurant we saw, as well as the one to grab our attention. We were taken to a table underground, which you can actually see from the sidewalk. The atmosphere felt very cozy, also thanks to the comfy chairs. One of the waiters seemed quite stressed (it was December 31st, around 3pm), but the rest of the staff and the floor manager were very attentive and caring. I ordered some rice with mushrooms, and it was so tasty!  I also had some dessert, cuz the list was truly inviting. I happened to hit the washrooms upstairs: it was so crowded, I was glad we were seated downstairs with fewer people and less noise. The overall price was worth the food and the service. If you are shopping around Serrano and want a good restaurant, this is the place.

review_preview: My wife and I and a friend had dinner here recently. La Bien Aperecida is a big "buzzy" restaurant with minimalist decor. It is one of three restaurants in Madrid under the same ownership. On the evening we were there the restaurant was busy and...
review_full: My wife and I and a friend had dinner here recently.  La Bien Aperecida is a big "buzzy" restaurant with minimalist decor. It is one of three restaurants in Madrid under the same ownership. On the evening we were there the restaurant was busy and we felt that the tables were very close to each other - not ideal for a quiet relaxing conversation. We found the menu and wine list interesting and varied - not overly long but proving enough choices for the majority of tastes. We really enjoyed the dishes we chose - in terms of quality of produce used, cooking and presentation. Our overall rating of four "stars" reflects our rating of the food: our rating for service would be lower - three stars or even three stars minus. As regards the service it was professional but we felt that there was something of the factory production line about it. The standard of food and service seemed to matter to the owners but equally, if not more important, seemed to be turning over the tables and maximising the nightly number of covers. Each course was delivered quickly after the other and at the end of the meal the bill appeared almost immediately. For us it would be somewhere to go to eat rather than an enjoy a fine dining experience with an equal emphasis on food and service. Although it was not for us, we would put it on our list of Madrid restaurants that friends might like to try.

The decor was very nice but we did not have much time to enjoy it.

If you're in Madrid, this is a must

title_review: One of our all time favourites!
review_preview: This  restaurant was right across the street from our hotel (hotel de  las letras) and was a Fodor's choice - so we tried it on our second night in Madrid.  The reception and service were impeccable. The food (Sea Bass and Cod) were outstanding and...
review_full: This restaurant was right across the street from our hotel (hotel de las letras) and was a Fodor's choice - so we tried it on our second night in Madrid. The reception and service were impeccable. The food (Sea Bass and Cod) were outstanding and great value. We liked it so much we went back the next night and tried different dishes (Hake and lamb chops) - again, everything was amazing. Like our hotel - Mercado de la Reina is a place I would have no problem recommending to anyone visiting Madrid.

title_review: Lively, trendy tapas bar on Gran Via.
review_preview: We were recommended this popular lively tapas bar by our hotel receptionist (Siete Islas).  We enjoyed it so much we went there twice.The draught beer (Cruzcampo) is nice but a tad expensive at 2.40euros for a small glass.  The wine is better value at...
review_full: We were recommended this popular lively tapas bar by our hotel receptionist (Siete Islas).  We enjoyed it so much we went there twice. The draught beer (Cruzcampo) is nice but a tad expensive at 2.40euros for a small glass. The wine is better value at 2.30euros for a glass/copa of Rioja or 2.70euros for Ribera del Duero. The tapas are very good and are all individually priced with no added iva or service charge. The tortilla espanola is particularly good. Well worth a visit for anyone staying in the Gran Via/Chueca area of Madrid.

Long live Spanish hospitality!
